author: John Doe
title: Introduction to React
content: This is the first post. It is a long established fact that a reader will be distracted by the readable content of a page when looking at its layout.

author: Jane Smith
title: Understanding Redux
content: Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript apps. It helps you write applications that behave consistently, run in different environments, and are easy to test.

author: Emily Clark
title: Getting Started with Vue.js
content: Vue.js is a progressive framework for building user interfaces. It is designed from the ground up to be incrementally adoptable.

author: John Doe
title: Exploring Node.js
content: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. It allows developers to use JavaScript for server-side scripting.

author: Mark Brown
title: Mastering TypeScript
content: TypeScript is a strongly typed programming language that builds on JavaScript, giving you better tooling at any scale.

author: Alice Green
title: CSS in Depth
content: CSS is used to control the style of a web document in a simple and easy way. It provides a powerful tool for web designers.

author: Brian Wilson
title: Understanding React Hooks
content: React Hooks allow you to use state and other React features without writing a class. It simplifies components and makes them more readable.

author: Sophia Turner
title: Web Accessibility Best Practices
content: Web accessibility means that websites, tools, and technologies are designed and developed so that people with disabilities can use them.

author: James Lee
title: Intro to GraphQL
content: GraphQL is a query language for APIs and a runtime for executing those queries by using a type system you define for your data.

author: Linda Johnson
title: Building with Next.js
content: Next.js is a React framework that enables server-side rendering and static site generation, making web applications faster and more scalable.
